overview_of_class: Our lives are reshaped daily by information technologies that didn't exist 20 (or even 10) years ago. That's not news, but change is so rapid that we barely have time to ask what kind of world we are creating. Are we now safer, smarter, happier, more democratic? Or more ignorant, isolated, indifferent, and anxious? This course will only scratch the surface, starting with a look at research into how technology has changed us; in the second half of the course, students will pursue their own research-based explorations into its effect on how we work, play, buy, vote, think, learn, love, and express ourselves.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
ENGLISH 110 or equivalent.

Before taking this class, students should have a basic understanding of English grammar and mechanics, and should be able to write clear, competent sentences using standard English. Students who need more basic writing instruction should enroll in ENGLISH 110.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on in-class work (20%), summary/response to assigned readings (20%) and three short research-based essays (20% each).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings will likely include excerpts from Neil Postman's Amusing Ourselves to Death, Nicolas Negroponte's Being Digital, and Steven Johnson's Everything Bad is Good for You, as well as numerous recent articles on digital culture and media.
